titleStmt.title: Compressive force‐induced autophagy in periodontal ligament cells downregulates osteoclastogenesis during tooth movement

funder.orgName: Science and Technology Commission of Shanghai Municipality
National Natural Science Foundation of China

affiliation.orgName: Shanghai Engineering Research Center of Tooth Restoration and Regeneration
Shanghai Engineering Research Center of Tooth Restoration and Regeneration
Shanghai Engineering Research Center of Tooth Restoration and Regeneration

analytic.title: Compressive force‐induced autophagy in periodontal ligament cells downregulates osteoclastogenesis during tooth movement

biblStruct.note: Received: 27 January 2019 Revised: 19 March 2019 Accepted: 28 April 2019

div.head: Background:
div.p: Autophagy has recently emerged as a protective mechanism in response to compressive force and an important process in maintenance of bone homeostasis.

It appears to be involved in the degradation of osteoclasts, osteoblasts, and osteocytes. The aim of this study was to investigate the role of compressive force-induced autophagy in periodontal ligament (PDL) cells in regulating osteoclastogenesis of orthodontic tooth movement (OTM).

div.head: Methods:
div.p: An OTM model and compressive force on PDL cells were employed to investigate the expression of autophagy markers in vivo and in vitro, respectively. Autophagosomes and autolysosomes were observed in PDL cells by transmission electron microscope (TEM) and autophagy LC3 double labelling. 3-Methyladenine (3-MA) and rapamycin were respectively used to inhibit and promote autophagy, and the effect of autophagy on osteoclastogenesis was explored via microcomputed tomography, hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining, histochemistry of titrate-resistant acid phosphatase, and real-time polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) in vivo. Receptor activator of nuclear factor-kappa B ligand/osteoprotegerin (RANKL/OPG) was investigated by RT-PCR and ELISA in vitro.

div.head: Results:
div.p: Orthodontic force-induced autophagy was prominent on the pressured side of PDL tissues. Administration of 3-MA downregulated bone density and upregulated osteoclasts, while rapamycin had reverse results in OTM. The autophagy activity increased initially then decreased in PDL cells during compressive force application and responded to light force. In PDL cells, administration of 3-MA upregulated while rapamycin downregulated the RANKL/OPG ratio.

div.head: Conclusion:
div.p: Autophagy is activated by compressive force in PDL cells. Besides, it could modulate OTM by negatively regulating osteoclastogenesis and keep bone homeostasis via RANKL/OPG signaling.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: Orthodontic tooth movement (OTM) occurs in response to compressive force applied for site-specific remodeling of periodontal ligament (PDL) and alveolar bone. 1 In general, orthodontic treatment has a positive effect on the supporting tissues. 2 However, it could cause harmful periodontal response including loss of alveolar bone and soft-tissue architecture, which may pose considerable challenges to oral rehabilitation. 3,4 Compressive force plays a crucial role in regulating osteoclasts in bone homeostasis both directly and indirectly. 5 It has been reported that compressive force can directly involve in osteoclastogenesis. Application of compressive force induced the differentiation of RAW264.7 cells into titrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP)-positive multinuclear cells. 6,7 Suture compression force can promote osteoclastogenesis leading to an increase in bone resorption and a decrease in bone density. 8 Compressive force could also affect osteoclasts through molecular transportation released by some other cells such as PDL cells. 9 PDL cells are subjected to compressive force in OTM, releasing various active cytokines including osteoprotegerin (OPG) and receptor activator of nuclear factor-kappa B ligand (RANKL), which affect osteoclasts to regulate the OTM process. [10][11][12] Autophagy is an evolutionarily conserved physical molecular process that degrades unwanted or dysfunctional organelles in cells. 13 The degraded materials are encapsulated by the double-membrane vesicles of autophagosomes, which fuse with lysosomes to form autolysosomes. After metabolism by autolysosomes, the degradation products are transported back to the cytoplasm for reuse. [14][15][16] Thus, autophagy has been suggested as a mechanism that protects cell survival and maintains cellular homeostasis. 14,15 Autophagy normally occurs in cells at low levels to maintain organelle homeostasis but is upregulated under some stress conditions. 17,18 Autophagy is increased in a variety of cells, such as human breast cancer cell lines, chondrocytes, human spironolactone-treated podocytes, and disc-derived nucleus pulposus cells, in response to compressive force. [19][20][21] An early study using electron microscopy showed that autophagy increased in PDL cells located on the pressured side of orthodontic teeth during OTM. 22 In addition, previous studies also found that autophagy had a profound effect on bone mineralization and homeostasis through the RANKL and OPG signaling pathway. 23,24 Autophagy proteins were demonstrated to have essential roles in generating the osteoclast ruffled border and bone resorption. 25 Pharmacological and genetic inhibition of autophagy reduced osteoclastogenesis and bone resorption, inhibiting bone loss caused by ovariectomy or glucocorticoid treatment. 26 However, the contributions of autophagy to the tissue response to compressive force during OTM remain unclear.
In this study, we attempted to investigate whether autophagy is induced in PDL cells by compressive force to regulate osteoclastogenesis in OTM.

div.head: Animals and the application of orthodontic force
div.p: Ninety-eight-week-old male C57BL/6 mice * weighing nearly 25 g were used in the study. All experimental protocols were approved by the Animal Use and Care Committee of Tongji University. The mice were kept under specific pathogen-free conditions at a controlled temperature (22 • C ± 1 • C) and humidity (40% to 60%) and with a 12-hour light/dark cycle. The mice were fed a soft diet and received water. OTM was established as previously described. 27 Briefly, a nickeltitanium coil spring † was fixed with resin between the left maxillary first molar and incisor to produce a pulling force to cause the first molar to move. The force was approximately 0.35 N, as measured by a dynamometer. The right side served as the control group. To evaluate the role of autophagy in OTM, mice were divided into four groups, including a control (n = 30), an orthodontic tooth movement (OTM; n = 30), a 3-methyladenine + tooth movement (3-MA + OTM; n = 30), and a rapamycin + tooth movement (RAPA + OTM; n = 30). The mice were subjected to orthodontic forces in addition to volumetrically equivalent intraperitoneal injection of 3-methyladenine (3-MA) ‡ at a dose of 15 mg/kg/d and rapamycin § at a dose of 0.75 mg/kg/d for 7 days.

div.head: Human PDL cell culture and force application
div.p: PDL cells were obtained from the orthodontically extracted healthy premolars of 13-to 18-year donors with informed consent. This study was approved by the Ethics Committee of Tongji University (SL2018R3). PDL cells were obtained from the middle third of the root surfaces of premolars and maintained as previously described. 28 PDL cells were seeded into 6-well plates at 10 5 cells/well and cultured to confluence. To apply compressive force, a glass plate was placed over the cells and covered with metal plates. In addition, PDL cells were treated with 1.5 mg/mL 3-MA ¶ and 5 µg/mL rapamycin # for 24 hours to mediate the level of autophagy in PDL cells to investigate the change of RANKL/OPG.

div.head: Autophagy LC3 double-labeling and autophagic flux assays
div.p: We sought to determine the locations of autophagosomes and autolysosomes in PDL cells. Cells were transfected with an mRFP-GFP-LC3 tandem lentivirus * according to the manufacturer's instructions. The PDL cells were grown in a CO 2 incubator at 37 • C for 2 hours and then force-loaded for 6 hours. After they were force loaded, autophagosomes and autolysosomes were detected and localized with a fluorescence microscope. † Red puncta were autolysosomes (mRFP), while yellow puncta indicated autophagosomes (RFP + GFP). The intensity of autophagy flux was determined by assessing the numbers of GFP-expressing and RFP-expressing cells. To assess the autophagic flux, 50 µM lysosomal inhibitor chloroquine ‡ was used to accumulate the autophagosomes and autolysosomes for 4 hours. LC3II/I and p62 § protein levels were test.

div.head: Micro-CT scanning
div.p: Microcomputed tomography (micro-CT) was used to scan the microarchitecture of the maxillary and quantify tooth movement distances between the distal height of the contour of the first molar and the mesial height of the contour of the second molar. The bone volume/tissue volume (BV/TV) ratio, bone mineral density (BMD), trabecular number (Tb.N), trabecular thickness (Tb.Th), and trabecular space (Tb.Sp) of the trifurcation area of the first molar were analyzed using self-contained three-dimensional analysis software in micro-CT. ¶

div.head: Histology analysis
div.p: Maxillae were collected on day 7 of OTM, fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde for 1 day and then decalcified in 10% EDTA (pH 7.4) for 30 days. The specimens were dehydrated in a series of alcohol baths beginning with 50% and progressing to 100% and embedded in paraffin and cut into cross sections at a thickness of 4 µm. Sections that included three roots and the alveolar bone of the first molar were selected for hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and titrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) staining. Tissue sections were observed with * Hanbio, Hanbio, Shanghai, China. † Nikon, NIKON, Tokyo, Japan. ‡ Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO. § BOSTER, Boster Biological Technology, Wuhan, China. ¶ ScanCo Medical, Bruttisellen, Switzerland. a confocal microscope. # The activated osteoclasts on the compressive side of the alveolar bone were analyzed.

div.head: Immunofluorescence staining
div.p: Tissue sections were stained with antibodies against LC3B ‖ and Beclin-1 * * to detect changes in autophagy expression. Then, sections were incubated with fluorescein secondary antibodies. † † Nuclei were counterstained with 4 ′ ,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI). Tissue sections were observed with the same confocal microscope.

div.head: Quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR)
div.p: Total RNA was extracted using TRIzol reagent ‡ ‡ from the periodontal tissues that surrounded the first molars or PDL cells according to the manufacturer's instructions. RNA was reverse transcribed to cDNA with a Transcription First-Strand cDNA Synthesis Kit § § according to the manufacturer's protocol, and the conditions of reactions were as follows: 30˚C for 10 minutes, 42˚C for 30 minutes, 99˚C for 5 minutes, and 4˚C for 5 minutes. Relative mRNA levels were determined using a SYBR Green PCR Master mix and a LightCycler 96 Instrument. ¶ ¶ GAPDH, a housekeeping gene, was used as a control.

div.head: Western blot analysis
div.p: Protein extracts were prepared from periodontal tissues of the first molar and from PDL cells. Tissues and cells were lysed in RIPA buffer-containing phenyl sulfonyl fluorine (PMSF) and phosphatase inhibitors. The protein concentrations of the samples were determined with a BCA kit. ## Protein samples (30 µg) were separated by sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and transferred to polyvinylidene fluoride membranes. The membranes were incubated with rabbit anti-Beclin-1, ‖‖ LC3B, * * * OPG, † † † RANKL/TNFSF11, ‡ ‡ ‡ or GAPDH § § § primary antibodies followed by secondary antibody for 2 hours and washed three times in TBST for 10 minutes each. Signals were detected using a chemiluminescence kit. *

div.head: Transmission electron microscopy
div.p: PDL cells were harvested, washed three times with phosphatebuffered saline, and fixed in 2.5% glutaraldehyde for 2 days at 4 • C. PDL cells were post-fixed in 1% osmium tetroxide for 2 hours. After they were dehydrated using a graded series of ethanol solutions, the samples were embedded in Embed-812 resin and cut into ultrathin sections (70 nm thick). The ultrathin sections were installed on a copper wire and stained with dioxyuranium acetate and lead citrate. These sections were examined with TEM. †

div.head: Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays
div.p: After treatment with 3-MA, rapamycin, and the application of compressive force, the supernatants of cultured PDL cells were collected and used for enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISAs) according to the manufacturer's instructions. ELISA was performed with commercial kits for OPG and RANKL. ‡

div.head: Statistical analysis
div.p: Data are presented as mean ± SEM. The statistical significance of differences among groups was determined by independent two-tailed Student t tests or one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA). P < 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

div.head: Orthodontic force-induced autophagy in PDL
div.p: To investigate whether orthodontic force induces autophagy, we established an OTM model (Fig. 1A). The expression levels of the essential autophagy proteins LC3II/I and Beclin-1 were higher on the side under orthodontic force than in the control group (Fig. 1B). In addition, the mRNA expression levels of the autophagy markers Atg5, Atg12, and Atg8/LC3 were also higher in the experimental group than in the control group (Fig. 1C). We further confirmed using immunofluorescence staining that LC3B and Beclin-1 levels were significantly higher in PDL cells after orthodontic force (Figs. 1D and 1E).

div.head: Compressive force regulated autophagy expression in PDL cells
div.p: To confirm whether autophagy is activated in PDL cells, we applied compressive force to PDL cells. First, we put 1.5 g/cm 2 compressive force to PDL cells for 3, 6, 9, 12, and 24 hours and the expression levels of LC3II/I and Beclin-1 were higher at 3, 6, and 9 hours (Fig. 2B). The mRNA expression levels of the autophagy markers Atg5, Atg12, and Atg8/LC3 followed a similar pattern (Fig. 2C). Then, we applied 1.5, 3.0, and 4.5 g/cm 2 compressive force to PDL cells for 6 hours and the expression levels of LC3II/I and Beclin-1 were significantly higher under 1.5 g/cm 2 compressive force (Fig. 2D). The mRNA expression levels of the autophagy markers Atg5 and Atg8/LC3 followed a similar pattern (Fig. 2E). To determine autophagic flux, PDL cells were treated with 50 µM chloroquine for 4 hours before harvest. Compressive force induced a reduction in p62 protein expression and an increase of LC3II/I protein expression, whereas treatment with chloroquine induced the accumulation of both p62 and LC3II/I (Fig. 2F). Next, we treated PDL cells with mRFP-GFP-LC3 adenovirus. The numbers of both mRFPpositive autophagosomes and double-positive autolysosomes per cell were significantly higher after 1.5 g/cm 2 compressive force (Fig. 2G). In this study, TEM was also used to confirm the effect of compressive force on autophagosome and autolysosomes formation. We found that the number of autophagosome and autolysosomes in the cytoplasm of PDL cells was higher after 6 hours of 1.5 g/cm 2 compressive force (Fig. 2H). These results suggest that autophagy appears in the early stage under compressive force and response to light compressive force in PDL cells.

div.head: Autophagy inhibited OTM and increased bone density
div.p: To explore the role of autophagy in OTM processes, animals were injected with the autophagy inhibitor 3-MA or the autophagy promoter rapamycin. Western blot results showed that 3-MA could downregulated autophagy of periodontal tissues and rapamycin upregulated autophagy in OTM model (Fig. 3A). Increased tooth movement distances were observed in the OTM animals. The distances were significantly larger in the 3-MA+ OTM group than in the OTM group. In contrast, tooth movement was significantly lower in the RAPA+ OTM group than in the OTM group (Figs. 3B through 3D). In addition, we found that OTM-induced changes of the morphology at the trifurcation of the first molar were autophagy dependent in micro-CT analysis. Micro-CT revealed a sparsely porous structure at the trifurcation of the root after OTM. A large cavity appeared on the bone at the trifurcation in 3-MA+ OTM group. However, rapamycin reduced OTM-induced changes of bone structure substantially at the trifurcation (Fig. 3E). BV/TV, BMD, Tb.N, and Tb.Th were lower, while Tb.Sp was significantly higher at the trifurcation area of the first molar after orthodontic force was applied for 7 days (Fig. 3F). H&E staining demonstrated that there were messier connective tissues on the bone at the first molar trifurcation after treatment of 3-MA, while the rapamycin group had no obvious change on the bone (Fig. 3G).

div.head: Autophagy inhibited osteoclastogenesis after orthodontic force
div.p: We next sought to further investigate how autophagy affects osteoclastogenesis, both of which are directly involved in bone remodeling during tooth movement. We administered 3-MA and rapamycin to OTM animals and observed a loss of structural integrity on the pressure side of the PDL in 3-MA-treated OTM animals. However, administration of rapamycin protected PDL tissues from both the loss of structural integrity (Fig. 4A). Compared with the control side, on the OTM side, TRAP staining indicated that injection of rapamycin significantly reduced the number of osteoclasts (Fig. 4B). RT-PCR showed that the mRNA expression levels of the osteoclast-related factors CTSK, matrix metalloproteinase-9, TRAP, and RANKL/OPG were significantly higher in cells treated with 3-MA during OTM. In contrast, rapamycin downregulated osteoclast activity (Fig. 4C). These results collectively demonstrate that autophagy inhibits osteoclastogenesis in OTM.

div.head: Autophagy induced by compressive force inhibited RANKL/OPG system
div.p: To further investigate the mechanism underlying how autophagy in PDL cells inhibits osteoclastic activity, we investigated the expression levels of RANKL/OPG. First, we investigated the expression of RANKL/OPG under compressive force and found that the ratio significantly increased, reached its highest level at 6 hours, and then decreased (Figs. 5A and 5B). To investigate the effect of autophagy on the expression of RANKL/OPG, 3-MA and rapamycin were administered to PDL cells and western blot results showed that 3-MA downregulated autophagy of PDL cells and rapamycin upregulated autophagy (Fig. 5C). Then, we used ELISA to test the protein levels of RANKL and OPG in supernatants obtained from cultured PDL cells that were treated with 6 hours of force loading. The results showed that the RANKL/OPG ratio increased under compressive force for 6 hours and was increased further by 3-MA in PDL cells under compressive force (Fig. 5D). We further found that 3-MA dramatically upregulated and rapamycin significantly downregulated the RANKL/OPG ratio of PDL cells under 1.5 g/cm 2 compressive force for 6 hours by RT-PCR (Fig. 5E), indicating that autophagy might negatively regulate osteoclastogenesis by regulating the balance between RANKL and OPG expression via autocrine and paracrine mechanisms.

div.head: DISCUSSION
div.p: Some studies have suggested that diverse cytokines and pathways are involved in compressive force-induced tooth movement. 29,30 In this study, we found that compressive force induced autophagy in PDL and PDL cells. We also found that autophagy in PDL and PDL cells downregulated osteoclastogenesis via RANKL/OPG during OTM.

Autophagy, a type of response initiated in response to stimulation by environmental change, maintains cellular functions and prevents mechanical damage when cells respond to chemical stimuli, such as starvation and hypoxia, as well as physical stimuli, such as compressive force. 22,31 Autophagy occurred in osteoblasts during experimental tooth movement; 32 and autophagy levels are higher in rat skeletal muscle after compression and oppose apoptotic responses. 33 However, whether autophagy is induced by compressive force in PDL, a type of connective tissue with some similarities with tendons in the appendage bones, 34 remained unknown. In this study, we found that the expression levels of the autophagy proteins LC3II/I and Beclin-1 in PDL tissues were significantly higher after 7 days of orthodontic force. In vivo, we used the ideal force 0.35 N for OTM in mice because of healthier periodontal condition and less side effects. 35 To simulate the PDL tissue environment under different orthodontic force levels in vivo, different compressive force levels was applied to PDL cells in vitro. We found that autophagy was sensitive to light compressive force. Autophagy adaption to different situations is described to take place in two phases first post-translational and in a delayed reaction on transcriptional level. 36 We test autophagy of PDL cells under compressive force in two phases but we could not find obvious trend and results in the second phase, suggesting that autophagy adaption to compressive force in PDL cells in vitro is a rapid response. We observed that compressive force significantly increased autophagy before it decreased over time in the first phase. Consistent with these findings, other studies have demonstrated that autophagy is rapidly initiated but transient because autophagy was reduced in cells that had already adapted to stress or in which essential autophagy proteins were cleaved by caspases under compressive force. 20,37 In this study, we chose autophagy proteins LC3II/I and Beclin-1 and autophagy genes Atg5, Atg12, and Atg8/LC3 because these markers are highly involved in the autophagy process. Autophagy proteins LC3II/I and Beclin-1 are required in the initial and late phases of autophagosome formation. Studies have shown that 18 Atg proteins are required for autophagosome formation and about half of Atg proteins comprise two ubiquitin-like conjugation systems, the Atg12-Atg5 and Atg8/LC3 systems, 38,39 which function at a late step of autophagosome formation, serving as good markers for the detection of membrane structures during autophagy. 14,40 The Atg12-Atg5 system is useful in localizing to the isolation membrane specifically and Atg8 system functions as formation of the autophagosome and fusion with lysosomes. 41,42 Autophagy is regarded as a new player in maintenance of skeletal homoeostasis, 43 which could occur during ossification such as endochondral ossification in wrist bone. 44 It is reported that rapamycin, an autophagy promoter, can promote the osteoblastic differentiation of human embryonic stem cells. 45 In our study, we found that bone resorption and bone density decreased under compressive force for 7 days and were associated with increased osteoclast counts and augmented expression of osteoclastic markers. What is the role of autophagy in PDL cells exposed to compressive force during this process? Rapamycin, an autophagy promoter, and 3-MA, an autophagy inhibitor, were used to regulate the levels of autophagy in PDL tissues. The results showed that injecting rapamycin into orthodontic mice significantly increased bone density at the bone anterior to the distobuccal root, while administration of 3-MA resulted in an opposite change in bone density. This result is consistent with the finding that rapamycin inhibited the expression of osteoclast-related factors and reduced the number of osteoclasts, while 3-MA caused opposite changes; and these results were consistent with previous studies showing that rapamycin reduced bone resorption in kidney transplant patients 46 and inhibited osteoclastogenesis in patients with giant cell tumors. 47 These data indicate that autophagy might regulate bone homeostasis by negatively regulating osteoclast activity and that autophagy might serve as a potential therapeutic target for diseases involving the overreaction of osteoclasts. Although the increase of autophagy reduces the speed of OTM, it has a good protective effect on periodontal tissues. Adjusting autophagy level may help keep balance of the speed of OTM and periodontal health. Some researchers have reported that autophagy proteins play essential roles in generating the osteoclast ruffled border and bone resorption. 25 This discrepancy could be attributable to the fact that autophagy plays different roles in cells. The role of autophagy in osteoclasts cannot be ignored during tooth movement, and we have demonstrated that autophagy affects PDL cells induced by orthodontic force during tooth movement. Autophagy mainly occurred in PDL cells during tooth movement, which caused PDL cells to secrete RANKL/OPG to inhibit osteoclastogenesis. Whether autophagy occurred in other cells, such as osteoclasts involved in OTM, and the specific mechanisms involved in these changes need to be further clarified.

Studies have shown that PDL cells can select and attract osteoclast precursors through the RANKL-RANK-OPG axis, causing them to migrate to the bone surface to form osteoclasts under compressive force. 48 PDL stem cells also can regulate osteoclastic activities through RANKL/OPG system. 9 In this study, we found that the RANKL/OPG ratio first increased before decreasing over time. The decreases in this ratio are most likely due to autophagy in PDL cells. To confirm this hypothesis, we examined the expression of autophagy markers and found that the RANKL/OPG ratio was lower when autophagy was promoted and higher when autophagy was inhibited.

div.head: CONCLUSIONS
div.p: Autophagy in PDL cells was activated under compressive force and regulated osteoclast activity by inhibiting the RANKL/OPG system. This study provides the first scientific evidence showing that autophagy plays a role during tooth movement. These findings increase our understanding of the biological mechanisms underlying the changes in dynamics that occur during tooth movement. In addition, the knowledge gained from the study might be useful for designing novel treatments in the future.

figure.head: F I G U R E 1
figure.figDesc: Autophagy increased in PDL tissues under orthodontic force. A) Diagrammatic sketch of OTM and representative image of the experimental OTM procedures in mice. A coil spring was ligated between the left maxillary first molar and the left incisor. B) Western blot results for LC3II/I and Beclin-1 in homogenates obtained from PDL tissues stimulated with orthodontic force for 7 days. C) Comparison of the mRNA expression levels of Atg5, Atg12, and Atg8/LC3 in PDL tissues obtained from the control and OTM groups after orthodontic force was applied for 7 days. D and E) Representative immunofluorescence images of the compressive sides of mesial roots. Dashed lines indicate the outlines of the roots. Arrows indicate the direction of force application. R, root. Scale bar = 100 µm. *P < 0.05 versus the control group

figure.head: F I G U R E 2
figure.figDesc: Compressive force-induced autophagy in PDL cells. A) PDL cells were treated with constant compressive force using cover slips and metal plates in the force group. B) LC3II/I and Beclin-1 protein expression levels in PDL cells under 1.5 g/cm 2 compressive force for 3, 6, 9, 12, and 24 hours. *P < 0.05 versus the 0-hour group. C) Atg5, Atg12, and Atg8/LC3 mRNA expression levels in PDL cells under 1.5 g/cm 2 compressive force. *P < 0.05 versus the 0-hour group. D) LC3II/I and Beclin-1 protein expression levels in PDL cells under 1.5, 3.0, and 4.5 g/cm 2 compressive force for 6 hours. † P < 0.05 versus the 0 g group. E) Atg5, Atg12, and Atg8/LC3 mRNA expression levels in PDL cells under 1.5, 3.0, and 4.5 g/cm 2 compressive force for 6 hours. † P < 0.05 versus the 0 g group. F) Autophagic flux detection of LC3II/I and p62 expression following the addition of 50 µM chloroquine for 4 hours before cell harvest. ‡ P < 0.05 versus the force (-) group. § P < 0.05 versus the force (+) group. G) The location of autophagosomes and autolysosomes in PDL cells. Yellow puncta indicate autophagosomes and red puncta indicate autolysosomes. They were around the cell nucleus. Scale bar = 5µm. H) Ultrastructural autophagic observation in PDL cells by TEM. Arrows indicate autophagosomes/autolysosomes in the cytoplasm of PDL cells. The right graph shows higher magnification views of the small boxes

figure.head: F I G U R E 3
figure.figDesc: OTM distances were decreased and bone density at the trifurcation area of the first molar was increased by autophagy in OTM. A) Western blot results for LC3II/I and Beclin-1 in homogenates obtained from PDL tissues injected by 3-MA or rapamycin for 7 days in OTM mice. B and C) Micro-CT images of the first and the second molars after 7 days in OTM mice. Arrows indicate the direction of orthodontic force. Bar = 100 µm. D) Distance between the first and the second molar after 7 days in OTM mice. E and F) Quantitative assessment of bone microstructure. Quantitative analysis including BV/TV, BMD, Tb.N, Tb.Th, and Tb.Sp in the trifurcation of the first molar. G) Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining of the horizontal section of the upper first molar. Arrows indicate the direction of orthodontic force. R, root. Bar = 100 µm. *P < 0.05 versus the control group. † P < 0.05 versus the OTM group

figure.head: F I G U R E 4
figure.figDesc: Autophagy inhibited the expression of osteoclasts in PDL tissues. A) H&E staining in PDL tissues. Arrows indicate the direction of orthodontic force. R, root; AB, alveolar bone; PDL, periodontal ligament; Bar = 50 µm. B) Representative TRAP staining in PDL tissues. Bar = 50 µm. Large boxed areas show higher magnification views of the small boxes. C) mRNA expression levels of CTSK, matrix metalloproteinase-9, TRAP, and RANKL/OPG. *P < 0.05 versus the control group. † P < 0.05 versus the OTM group

figure.head: F I G U R E 5
figure.figDesc: Effects of autophagy on the expression of RANKL and OPG in PDL cells. A and B) Western blot and RT-PCR results showing RANKL and OPG expression under compressive force in PDL cells. *P < 0.05 versus the 0-hour group. C) Western blot results for LC3II/I and Beclin-1 in PDL cells injected by 3-MA or rapamycin. † P < 0.05 versus the control group. D and E) ELISA and RT-PCR analysis of the levels of OPG and RANKL in PDL cells treated with compressive force and 3-MA or rapamycin. ‡ P < 0.05 versus the control group. § P < 0.05 versus the force group

div.head: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
div.p: Master L. Chen performed all experiments, interpreted the results, and prepared the manuscript. Master S. Mo contributed to the conception and design of the study and drafted and critically revised the manuscript. Prof. Y. Hua conceived the idea for the project, supervised the project, and critically revised the manuscript. All authors gave final approval and agreed to be accountable for all aspects of the work. This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 81870791, China) and the Science and Technology Commission of Shanghai Municipality (No.17140903700, Shanghai, China). All authors have contributed to, seen, and approved the final submitted version of the manuscript. We hereby declare that this is an original manuscript, has not been sent elsewhere, that we do not have commercial or other associations that might pose a conflict of interest, and that the study has been conducted according to the highest principals of animal welfare. The authors report no conflicts of interest related to this study.
